 Since the ${\varphi}_j$'s are decreasing, it is natural to expect that these measures converge (in the weak sense).
The following strong monotonicity property holds:

\begin{lem}
The sequence
$
\mu_j:={\bf 1}_{\{ {\varphi}>-j\}} MA({\varphi}_j)
$
is an increasing sequence of Borel measures.
\end{lem}

The class ${\mathcal E}(X,\omega)$ also contains many $\omega$-psh functions which are unbounded.
When $X$ is a compact Riemann surface ($n=\dim_{{\mathbb{C}}} X=1$),
the set ${\mathcal E}(X,{\omega})$ is the set of ${\omega}$-sh functions
whose Laplacian does not charge polar sets.

\begin{rem}
If ${\varphi} \in PSH(X,\omega)$ is normalized so that ${\varphi} \leq -1$, then $-(-{\varphi})^{\varepsilon} $ belongs to
${\mathcal E}(X,{\omega})$ whenever $0 \leq {\varepsilon} <1$.
The functions which belong to the class ${\mathcal E}(X,{\omega})$,
although usually unbounded,
have relatively mild singularities. In particular they have zero Lelong numbers.
\end{rem}

These classes therefore coincide in dimension $n=1$, but the inclusions are strict in general when
$n \geq 2$: the first inclusion is sharp for functions with divisorial singularities (Proposition \ref{prop:div}),
while the second inclusion is sharp for functions with compact singularities (Proposition \ref{prop:compact}).

We briefly describe the range of the complex Monge-Amp\`ere operator acting on Choquet classes
in Proposition \ref{prop:range} and Proposition \ref{pro:MA2}. This description is not as complete as the
corresponding one for finite energy classe in \cite{GZ07};
Choquet classes are rather meant to become a useful intermediate tool in the analysis
of the complex Monge-Amp\`ere operator.





\section{Choquet classes}



\subsection{Choquet capacity}


\subsubsection{Generalized capacities}

Let $\Omega$ be a Hausdorff
locally compact topological space which we  assume is $\sigma$-compact.
We denote by $2^{\Omega}$ the set of all subsets of $\Omega$.
A set function $ c : 2^{\Omega} \longrightarrow \bar{{\mathbb{R}}}^+ := [0, + \infty]$ is
called a capacity on $\Omega$ if it satisfies the following four properties:

\smallskip

$(i)$ $c(\emptyset) = 0$;

\smallskip

$(ii)$ $c$ is monotone, i.e.
$
 A \subset B \subset \Omega \Longrightarrow 0 \leq c(A) \leq c(B);
$

\begin{proof}
Set $\chi(t)=-(-t)^{p+j}$.
The proof is slightly different if $j=0$ and $0 < p<1$ or if $p+j \geq 1$
($\chi$ is convex or concave). We only treat the second case and leave the modifications to the reader.
Observe that
$0 \leq \chi'(2t) =M  \chi'(t)$, with $M=2^{p+j-1}$, hence
\begin{eqnarray*}
\int_X (-\chi) \circ {\varphi} \, {\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j&=&
\int_{-\infty}^0 \chi'(t) {\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j ({\varphi} <t) dt \\
&\leq&  2M\int_{-\infty}^0 \chi'(t) {\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j ({\varphi} <2t) dt.
\end{eqnarray*}
Now $({\varphi} <2t) \subset ({\varphi}<{\psi}+t) \cup ({\psi}<t)$, hence
$0 \leq \chi'(2t) =M  \chi'(t)$, with $M=2^{p+j-1}$, hence
\begin{eqnarray*}
\int_X (-\chi) \circ {\varphi} \, {\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j&\leq&
2M \int_{-\infty}^0 \chi'(t) {\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j ({\varphi} <{\psi}+t) dt \\
&+&  2M \int_X (-\psi)^{p+j} \omega_{\psi}^{n - j} \wedge \omega^j.
\end{eqnarray*}
The comparison principle yields
${\omega}_{{\psi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j ({\varphi}<{\psi}+t) \leq  {\omega}_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j ({\varphi}<{\psi}+t)$.
The desired inequality follows by observing that
$({\varphi}<{\psi}+t) \subset ({\varphi}<t)$.
\end{proof}

The inclusions
$\mathcal E^{p+n-1} (X,\omega) \subset \mathcal Ch^p (X,\omega) \subset \mathcal E^p (X,\omega)$
are strict  in general when $n \geq 2$, as we show in Example \ref{exa:contre} below .

\begin{proof}
Let $V$ be a neighborhood of $D$ where ${\varphi}$ is bounded.
For simplicity we assume that $c_1(D)=\{\omega\}$. Let $\omega'$ be a smooth semi-positive closed
form cohomologous to $\omega$, such that $\omega' \equiv 0$ outside $V$. Let $\rho$ be a smooth
$\omega$-psh function such that $\omega'=\omega+dd^c \rho$. Shifting by a constant, we can
assume that $0 \leq \rho \leq M$. Observe that
{\small
\begin{eqnarray*}
-dd^c (-{\varphi})^{p+j} &=&-(p+j)(p+j-1) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-2} d {\varphi} \wedge d^c {\varphi} +(p+j) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{\varphi} \\
&\leq&  (p+j) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{\varphi}.
\end{eqnarray*}
}
Therefore
\begin{eqnarray*}
\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j &=&
\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge \omega'  \\
& + & \int -(-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge dd^c \rho \\
&=& O(1)+\int \rho \, dd^c [-(-{\varphi})^{p+j}] \wedge \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1}  \\
& \leq & O(1)+(p+j)M \int (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j+1} \wedge \omega^{j-1}.
\end{eqnarray*}

We denote here by $O(1)$ the first term
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge \omega' $ which is bounded, since
${\varphi}$ is bounded on the support of $\omega'$.

By induction we obtain that each term
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j$ is controlled by
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p} \omega_{{\varphi}}^n$. Thus $\rm{Ch}_p({\varphi})$ is finite if and only if so is
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p} \omega_{{\varphi}}^n$.
\end{proof}


This proposition allows us to cook up examples of $\omega$-psh functions ${\varphi}$

such that ${\varphi} \in \mathcal Ch^p(X,\omega)$ but ${\varphi} \notin {\mathcal{E}}^{p+n-1}(X,\omega)$.

$\mathcal E (X,{\omega})$.

The inclusions
$\mathcal E^{p+n-1} (X,\omega) \subset \mathcal Ch^p (X,\omega) \subset \mathcal E^p (X,\omega)$
are strict  in general when $n \geq 2$, as we show in Example \ref{exa:contre} below .

\begin{proof}
Let $V$ be a neighborhood of $D$ where ${\varphi}$ is bounded.
For simplicity we assume that $c_1(D)=\{\omega\}$. Let $\omega'$ be a smooth semi-positive closed
form cohomologous to $\omega$, such that $\omega' \equiv 0$ outside $V$. Let $\rho$ be a smooth
$\omega$-psh function such that $\omega'=\omega+dd^c \rho$. Shifting by a constant, we can
assume that $0 \leq \rho \leq M$. Observe that
{\small
\begin{eqnarray*}
-dd^c (-{\varphi})^{p+j} &=&-(p+j)(p+j-1) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-2} d {\varphi} \wedge d^c {\varphi} +(p+j) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{\varphi} \\
&\leq&  (p+j) (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{\varphi}.
\end{eqnarray*}
}
Therefore
\begin{eqnarray*}
\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j &=&
\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge \omega'  \\
& + & \int -(-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge dd^c \rho \\
&=& O(1)+\int \rho \, dd^c [-(-{\varphi})^{p+j}] \wedge \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1}  \\
& \leq & O(1)+(p+j)M \int (-{\varphi})^{p+j-1} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j+1} \wedge \omega^{j-1}.
\end{eqnarray*}

We denote here by $O(1)$ the first term
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^{j-1} \wedge \omega' $ which is bounded, since
${\varphi}$ is bounded on the support of $\omega'$.

By induction we obtain that each term
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p+j} \omega_{{\varphi}}^{n-j} \wedge \omega^j$ is controlled by
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p} \omega_{{\varphi}}^n$. Thus $\rm{Ch}_p({\varphi})$ is finite if and only if so is
$\int (-{\varphi})^{p} \omega_{{\varphi}}^n$.
\end{proof}


This proposition allows us to cook up examples of $\omega$-psh functions ${\varphi}$

such that ${\varphi} \in \mathcal Ch^p(X,\omega)$ but ${\varphi} \notin {\mathcal{E}}^{p+n-1}(X,\omega)$.
The next example shows how to cook up examples such that ${\varphi} \in {\mathcal{E}}^p(X,\omega)$ but
${\varphi} \notin \mathcal Ch^p(X,\omega)$:




\begin{exa}   \label{exa:contre}

${\alpha}$ is the Fubini-Study form on $\mathbb  {\mathbb{C}} {\mathbb{P}}^{n - 1}$ and ${\beta}$ is the Fubini-Study form on

The function ${\varphi}$ defined by  ${\varphi} (x,y) := u (x) + v (y)$ for $(x,y) \in X$ belongs to
$\mathcal E (X,{\omega})$.
Moreover ${\omega}_{{\varphi}} = {\alpha}_u + {\beta}_v$ and for any $1 \leq \ell \leq n$, we have
